repo.description: Apache Airflow - A platform to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor workflows

title: Use proper signal handling and cascade signals to children (Fix #852)
body:
This fixes ISSUE-#852 by starting gunicorn with a pid file and to exit immediately after that. This makes airflow's webserver behave more standard. To retain old behavior you can specify "-f" or "--foreground". 
- the pid file is placed in AIRFLOW_HOME/airflow-webserver.pid or if you are running systemd in /run/airflow/webserver.pid. If you want to store it somewhere else please use "--pid" as an argument.
- systemd profile for the webserver is now a bit more secure 
- if you are running systemd make sure to follow the instructions otherwise you might have some write permission issues for storing the pid file.

title: Add a Gitter chat badge to README.md
body:
### airbnb/airflow now has a Chat Room on Gitter

@mistercrunch has just created a chat room. You can visit it here: [https://gitter.im/airbnb/airflow](https://gitter.im/airbnb/airflow?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&content=body_link).

This pull-request adds this badge to your README.md:

[![Gitter](https://badges.gitter.im/airbnb/airflow.svg)](https://gitter.im/airbnb/airflow?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&utm_content=body_badge)

If my aim is a little off, please [let me know](https://github.com/gitterHQ/readme-badger/issues).

Happy chatting.

PS: [Click here](https://gitter.im/settings/badger/opt-out) if you would prefer not to receive automatic pull-requests from Gitter in future.

title: Feature/cli fixes
body:
Corrected a duplicated help text.
Also pulled a workaround from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23349349/argparse-with-required-subparser so that "airflow" prints help rather than an ugly help with python3 (Ubuntu 14.04):

Was:

```
[2016-01-05 22:31:02,400] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python3.4/lib2to3/Grammar.txt
[2016-01-05 22:31:02,429] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python3.4/lib2to3/PatternGrammar.txt
[2016-01-05 22:31:02,553] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor CeleryExecutor
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/airflow/bin/airflow", line 15, in <module>
    args.func(args)
AttributeError: 'Namespace' object has no attribute 'func'
```

Now

```
2016-01-05 22:14:43,790] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python3.4/lib2to3/Grammar.txt
[2016-01-05 22:14:43,820] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python3.4/lib2to3/PatternGrammar.txt
[2016-01-05 22:14:43,943] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor CeleryExecutor
usage: airflow [-h]
               {backfill,clear,trigger_dag,run,test,task_state,webserver,scheduler,initdb,resetdb,upgradedb,list_dags,list_tasks,worker,serve_logs,flower,version,kerberos}
               ...
airflow: error: the following arguments are required: subcommand
```

title: End-to-end DAG testing
body:
### Overview

This PR adds an end-to-end dag tester to Airflow, located in `tests_dags/dag_tester.py`, as well as some DAG tests located in `tests_dags/tests/bash_operator_dag_tests.py`

These tests require a connection to a concurrent db (i.e. not SQLite) in the `sql_alchemy_conn` field of your `unittests.cfg`. The tests will be skipped otherwise.
### How to use
- The test author creates one or several DAG files and store them in `tests_dags/dags`. 
- The test author provides one or several units test for the dag(s), (cf examples in `tests_dags/tests/bash_operator_dag_tests.py`). This test should provide: 
  - `get_dag_file_names` to specify which dag files are involved in this test
  - `get_context` (optional): a dictionary of `Variable` to be provided to the DAG at test time
  - if we want to test the dags with a `BackfillJob`, inherit from `EndToEndBackfillJobTest` and  implement `get_backfill_params` to specify the constructor parameters of `BackfillJob`. 
  - if we want to test the dags with a `SchedulerJob`, inherit from `EndToEndSchedulerJobTest` and  implement `get_schedulerjob_params` to specify the constructor parameters of `SchedulerJob`
  - implement `post_check` with a set of post-execution validation steps 
- The DAG created by the test author may access the name of their runtime temporary folder with `Variable.get("unit_test_tmp_dir")` as well as any other context parameter provided by the test. For example, if the test implements this:
  
  ```
  def get_context(self):
      return {"country": "India",
              "product_sample_size": 10000}
  ```
  
  then the DAG will be able to access those values at test time via: 
  
  ```
  Variable.get(key="country", deserialize_json=True)
  Variable.get(key="product_sample_size", deserialize_json=True)
  ```
- The design of the test should keep in mind that the executors are ultimately starting child processes via some `airflow run blah` commands. This is particularly important to design the interactions between the test initialization, its running, and the validation of post-conditions, since they do not all run within the same python process. 
### How it works

The DAG Tester will:
- create a temporary folder for each test and copy all the tested DAGs in a subfolder `dags` of that folder
- copy an airflow configuration file to that temporary folder, adapts its `dags_folder` value according to the above. 
- write in `Variables` the location of the temporary folder in `unit_test_tmp_dir` as well as all the values provided by the test in `get_context`. (If any `Variables` would have been overwritten in the process, their values are saved and restored during `cleanup`)
- depending on what is implemented by the test, build a `BackfillJob` and/or a `SchedulerJob` with the tested dags and run it
- after each run, execute the test `post_check`
### Future possible improvements
- we currently only run the test with a `BackfillJob` with a `SequencialExecutor` and/or with a `SchedulerJob` with a `LocalExcecutor`. We could add more executors and combinations
- each test is executed with its own config file, though it's almost the same for every test => we could extend the framework to validate different kinds of configurations per test
- all tests provided so far are validating the `BashOperator`, though adding more kinds of operator should be straightforward. 
- we could extend it to run the job several times, maybe thus allowing to validate restartability of a DAG (e.g. a whole DAG that fails twice before succeeding), idempotency (a DAG that is executed several times with the same `execution_date`, with a `clear` between each run, should not produce corrupted output) or simulating addition/removal/update of DAG files between successive executions.
- we could try to extend to execution of several jobs in parallel, thus improving the validation of race condition (although test of parallel code is always tricky) 
### Limitations
- The `num_runs` parameter for `SchedulerJob` tests is artificially high in some cases, we do not always understand why more `DagRun`s than the theoretical number are needed. This has an impact on the execution time.
- The execution time of the 7 DAG tests with both kinds of executors over a period of up to 10 days requires about 20 minutes to execute on Travis => we might need to discuss when we want execute them.

repo.name: airflow
repo.description: Apache Airflow - A platform to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor workflows

title: Fix base_url in http hook to always start with http://
body:
When we use environment variables to make Http connections, it reads http:// from string and remove it. This fact made to not be able connecting because cannot find location (even localhost or 127.0.0.1).

Other way to recreate this bug is create an Http connection from webserver-ui without specifying http:// in host field.

This minor check add http:// at the start if host string doen't got it.

repo.name: airflow
repo.description: Apache Airflow - A platform to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor workflows

title: Removed logging sql query that exposes credentials
body:
# Purpose

Although most of the time, logs are only exposed to internal systems/people, it is unsafe to show credentials in plain text anywhere. Technologies that only allow passing credentials with a query could potentially pose a problem in this context when all the sql queries executed are shown in logs. Maybe this could be added back when airflow has a debug mode, but definitely a security risk.

For example, AWS redshift authenticates with aws credentials with their COPY command which looks like this in logs:

```
[2015-12-09 21:12:21,228] {dbapi_hook.py:97} INFO - COPY some_table_name from 's3://airflow/folder/table' credentials 'aws_access_key_id=XXXX;aws_secret_access_key=YYYY';
```

repo.description: AirFlow is a system to programmatically author, schedule and monitor data pipelines.

repo.name: airflow
repo.description: Apache Airflow - A platform to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor workflows

title: Get connection string containing username and password during runtime
body:
The purpose of this is to not expose the username and passwords in the configuration file on the production machine.

In case when configuration.get('core', SQL_ALCHEMY_CONN / BROKER_URL / CELERY_RESULT_BACKEND) is EMPTY, fallback to check the value of corresponding fallback key say SQL_ALCHEMY_CONN_CMD. If the fallback value is valid then run bash command on it and return the result.

Right now, only those 3 keys use the callback because they contain username and passwords. But this can be the general rule of thumb if needed.

I can add tests for this if you'll be interested in this PR. @mistercrunch 

UPDATE: I've added tests and added an entry to the doc.

title: improved logs readability and config
body:
- passing --logging-level=DEBUG  at the command line is no longer ignored
- classes can now implement `WithLogger` to get access to convenience logging function (e.g. `self.log_info("blah"))`, producing log statement with a logger whose name is the name of the class. The resulting log statements look like this:

```
2015-12-07 17:22:43,084 - BackfillJob - INFO - [backfill progress] waiting: 0 | succeeded: 1 | kicked_off: 1 | failed: 0 | wont_run: 0
2015-12-07 17:22:43,084 - SequentialExecutor - DEBUG - Calling the <class 'airflow.executors.sequential_executor.SequentialExecutor'> sync method
2015-12-07 17:22:43,084 - SequentialExecutor - DEBUG - 0 running task instances
2015-12-07 17:22:43,084 - SequentialExecutor - DEBUG - 0 in queue
2015-12-07 17:22:43,084 - SequentialExecutor - DEBUG - 32 open slots
2015-12-07 17:22:43,085 - BackfillJob - INFO - All done. Exiting.
```
- configured this WithLogger super class in a couple of key existing classes to improve current log readability.

title: Unit tests for duplicate dependencies and cyclic dependencies
body:
We've added some unit tests to test that duplicate dependencies are detected, as well as cycles.

Also, some minor plastic surgery changes :
- Replace some `self.append_only_new` with `task.append_only_new` to make sure that `BaseOperator` always adds task to its protected `_downstream_list` or `_upstream_list`
- Change the order of `.append_only_new`s to alway get an error message of the form `Dependency {upstream_task}, {downstream_task} already registered` when duplicate dependencies are added.

title: Fix DagBag.get_dag() for non existing dag_id
body:
Calling `.get_dag("non_existing_dag_id")` was previously leading to a crash related to a call to `None.fileloc`. We've fixed the bug by allowing the code to return None when the DAG isn't found, following the existing logic that is already returning `None` in other cases where the Dag isn't found.

We've also added unit tests to validate the behavior

title: Run docker containers
body:
This PR adds support for running docker containers by adding a
`DockerOperator`.

Besides starting a container, the implementation supports pulling
images, limiting resources, mounting volumes, setting the network
mode and authenticating via TLS.

title: [AIRFLOW-594] Load plugins and workflows from packages
body:
This pull request adds capabilities to load plugins and workflows from other packages via the setuptools entry point mechanism.

Within my company (http://blue-yonder.com) we are currently evaluating whether we could use airflow. As our infrastructure is suited towards the deployment of python packages we would need a way to load workflows from installed packages. Also for plugins the entry point mechanism seems very natural.

If you have any ideas or comments on this feature (or how to properly test it) we are happy to discuss it here!

title: fix bytestring in xcom with python3
body:
Hi,
There is an issue with python3 and the `str` function, which translate
`"output_from_bash"` to `b"output_from_bash"`

as stated here https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html?highlight=str#str

I had issues with jinja templating and saw "b" string in the rendered template.

title: improve SQLAlchemy session management in models.py
body:
- the optional creation and closing of local session in case no main_session is present is now encapsulated in a class that can be invoked via a simple with statement
- local sessions are now correctly closed in case of Exception during the method execution: previous load of try/except statement could potentially lead to un-closed sessions
- 4 supplementary UT to validate all that
- slightly more concise code :D

title: DAG_FOLDER synchronizer
body:
This PR implements, in a very early stage, a synchronizer for the dag_folder. This is done by exposing an  REST API on the web server. This can be triggered by, for example, a GitLab web hook. The synchronizer then updates the folder by, configurable, a git pull. This makes it easier to keep dag_folders in sync across different workers and have them updated when new dags are available. 

@mistercrunch I'm looking for feedback on the approach isn't really ready yet for merging.

title: Better logging
body: This PR removes the hack in the executors/**init**.py by only importing executors when specified to do so. It is assumed (in views.py) that a failure to import CeleryExecutor means it is not active anyway and thus a run() fails accordingly. Furthermore it adds logging to sections/keys that are non existent in a config so debugging config issues becomes easier.
